text: Libya is an unstable country a place
where militias compete for power where
the Islamic state group has a foothold
where migrants pour across unprotected
borders or route for the sea a chaotic
picture which MPs say is the result of
David Cameron's decision five years ago
to send in warplanes to support rebels
fighting Colonel Gaddafi we were not
prepared for - for the consequences of a
regime change in Libya and all the
analysis being done here was based on
frankly a pretty limited understanding
of exactly what the situation in Libya
was the aim of the intervention in march
2011 was to protect the people living in
benghazi threatened by Gaddafi's forces
but the Foreign Affairs Committee says
the threat to civilians was overstated
by inaccurate intelligence now over the
summer as fighting continued the aim of
the operation changed from protecting
civilians to getting rid of Gaddafi and
the committee said this was an
opportunist policy of regime change that
was not underpinned by a strategy to
support Libya afterwards in particular
the MPS aim or should have been done to
use Tony Blair's contacts to see if a
political deal was possible a conclusion
that one former rebel leader rejects out
of hand
he thinks Gaddafi just had to go Libya
would have been much worse than it is
now the situation in Libya would have
been something like Syria or maybe more
chaotic in September 2011 after
Gaddafi's regime had fallen mr. Cameron
and the then French president visited
Libya and told the people they had shown
the courage of lions and France will
stand with you as you build your
democracy and build your country for the
future and yet the Foreign Affairs
Committee says that this did not happen
and David Cameron was ultimately
responsible for the failure to develop a
coherent Libya strategy but diplomats
and ministers involved in the decision
to intervene said it was backed by MPs
the United Nations it was responding to
a real threat there wasn't clear that
leaving Gaddafi in place would have
ensured a better outcome in Iraq we went
in with major forces it didn't turn out
very well in Syria we chose not to get
involved I mean that's also catastrophic
in Libya we went in in a limited
targeted way in support of insurgents on
the ground yes the situation is bad but
I wouldn't rule out at all that in five
years the various parties will have got
together and begun to build something in
Libya but the situation on the ground
makes such optimism rare in Libya
politics still comes second to violence
James Lyndell BBC News
